description: System-level mandate says 'Use TodoWrite VERY frequently' and 'always use the TodoWrite tool to plan and track tasks throughout the conversation.' The commit workflow explicitly prohibits: 'NEVER use the TodoWrite or Task tools.' A model in a commit context must violate one or the other.
evidence: Block A: 'Use these tools VERY frequently to ensure that you are tracking your tasks' / Block B: 'NEVER use the TodoWrite or Task tools'

description: Reinforcement of TodoWrite mandate ('IMPORTANT: Always use the TodoWrite tool to plan and track tasks throughout the conversation') directly contradicts commit workflow prohibition ('NEVER use the TodoWrite or Task tools'). 'Always' vs 'NEVER' with no declared scoping mechanism.
evidence: Block A: 'IMPORTANT: Always use the TodoWrite tool to plan and track tasks throughout the conversation.' / Block B: 'NEVER use the TodoWrite or Task tools'

description: Same pattern as commit workflow: general TodoWrite mandate conflicts with PR workflow prohibition. The PR workflow says 'DO NOT use the TodoWrite or Task tools' while the general mandate says use TodoWrite VERY frequently.
evidence: Block A: 'Use these tools VERY frequently' / Block B: 'DO NOT use the TodoWrite or Task tools'

description: Reinforced TodoWrite mandate ('Always') vs PR workflow prohibition ('DO NOT use the TodoWrite or Task tools'). Same contradiction pattern as commit workflow.
evidence: Block A: 'Always use the TodoWrite tool' / Block B: 'DO NOT use the TodoWrite or Task tools'

description: System-level mandate says 'Use TodoWrite VERY frequently' and 'if you do not use this tool when planning, you may forget to do important tasks - and that is unacceptable.' But the tool's own definition says 'When NOT to Use This Tool: single straightforward task, trivial tasks (<3 steps), conversational/informational.' The mandate is unconditional; the tool definition adds exceptions.
evidence: Block A: 'Use these tools VERY frequently... that is unacceptable' / Block B: 'When NOT to Use This Tool: There is only a single, straightforward task; The task is trivial; The task can be completed in less than 3 trivial steps'

description: Verbatim duplicate of security policy text at lines 40 and 145. Is this reinforcement or does position matter? Models may weight later instructions differently. No mechanism declares whether repetition changes priority.
evidence: Identical text at two locations: 'IMPORTANT: Assist with authorized security testing...' appears at lines 40-41 and again at line 145

description: Conciseness mandate ('responses should be short and concise') creates tension with TodoWrite mandate ('use VERY frequently'). Frequent TodoWrite calls add overhead text describing task management steps, making responses longer. The model must balance brevity with demonstrating task tracking.
evidence: Block A: 'Your responses should be short and concise' / Block B: 'Use these tools VERY frequently to ensure that you are tracking your tasks and giving the user visibility into your progress'

description: Conciseness mandate conflicts with WebSearch's requirement to append a Sources section with URLs after every search-based response. The sources section adds mandatory length to responses.
evidence: Block A: 'Your responses should be short and concise' / Block B: 'CRITICAL REQUIREMENT: you MUST include a Sources section at the end of your response'

description: General tool policy says 'prefer to use the Task tool' for file search. But explore agent guidance says 'use this only when a simple, directed search proves to be insufficient or when your task will clearly require more than 3 queries.' One says prefer delegation, the other says only delegate when simple search fails.
evidence: Block A: 'When doing file search, prefer to use the Task tool' / Block B: 'This is slower than calling Glob or Grep directly so use this only when a simple, directed search proves to be insufficient'

description: Read-before-modify constraint stated in two places with different enforcement. General policy: behavioral norm ('NEVER propose changes to code you haven't read'). Tool definition: technical enforcement ('This tool will error if you attempt an edit without reading'). Same intent, different mechanisms, no cross-reference.
evidence: Block A: 'NEVER propose changes to code you haven't read' / Block B: 'You must use your Read tool at least once in the conversation before editing. This tool will error if you attempt an edit without reading the file.'

description: Read-before-modify constraint stated in general policy and repeated in Write tool definition. Triple enforcement of same rule across doing-tasks, Edit, and Write blocks.
evidence: Block A: 'NEVER propose changes to code you haven't read' / Block B: 'If this is an existing file, you MUST use the Read tool first to read the file's contents. This tool will fail if you did not read the file first.'

description: File creation restriction stated in tone section (general) and again in Write tool (specific, with added markdown restriction). The Write tool adds 'NEVER proactively create documentation files (*.md) or README files' which narrows the general prohibition for a specific file type.
evidence: Block A: 'NEVER create files unless they're absolutely necessary for achieving your goal. ALWAYS prefer editing an existing file.' / Block B: 'ALWAYS prefer editing existing files in the codebase. NEVER write new files unless explicitly required. NEVER proactively create documentation files (*.md) or README files.'

description: File creation restriction from tone section overlaps with Edit tool's 'ALWAYS prefer editing existing files in the codebase. NEVER write new files unless explicitly required.' Same behavioral constraint, different locations.
evidence: Block A: 'NEVER create files unless they're absolutely necessary' / Block B: 'ALWAYS prefer editing existing files in the codebase. NEVER write new files unless explicitly required.'

description: Bash usage restriction stated in both the general tool policy ('Use specialized tools instead of bash commands when possible') and the Bash tool definition itself ('DO NOT use it for file operations - use the specialized tools'). Same constraint, two enforcement points.
evidence: Block A: 'Reserve bash tools exclusively for actual system commands and terminal operations' / Block B: 'This tool is for terminal operations like git, npm, docker, etc. DO NOT use it for file operations'

description: Bash restriction from general tool policy overlaps with Grep tool's own prohibition: 'ALWAYS use Grep for search tasks. NEVER invoke grep or rg as a Bash command.' Three places now say the same thing: tool policy, Bash tool def, and Grep tool def.
evidence: Block A: 'Use specialized tools instead of bash commands when possible' / Block B: 'ALWAYS use Grep for search tasks. NEVER invoke grep or rg as a Bash command.'

description: No-time-estimates prohibition exists as its own section AND is partially restated in the asking-questions block ('never include time estimates - focus on what each option involves, not how long it takes'). Same rule, duplicated in a narrower scope.
evidence: Block A: 'Never give time estimates or predictions for how long tasks will take' / Block B: 'When presenting options or plans, never include time estimates'

description: Commit workflow restriction says 'NEVER run additional commands to read or explore code, besides git bash commands.' But the general Bash tool policy says 'DO NOT use it for file operations - use the specialized tools.' During a commit, you must use Bash for git commands but the general policy restricts Bash usage. The commit workflow implicitly overrides the general bash restriction for git-specific operations without declaring this.
evidence: Block A: 'NEVER run additional commands to read or explore code, besides git bash commands' / Block B: 'This tool is for terminal operations like git, npm, docker'

description: Plan mode (via Plan agent type in Task tool) restricts Edit, Write, NotebookEdit tools. But the general tool policy mandates using dedicated tools instead of Bash for file operations. In plan mode, the agent can't use Edit/Write but also shouldn't use Bash for file operations. This creates a dead zone where file modification is impossible, which is likely intentional but undeclared.
evidence: Plan agent: 'Tools: All tools except Task, ExitPlanMode, Edit, Write, NotebookEdit' / Tool policy: 'Reserve bash tools exclusively for actual system commands'

description: No-emoji rule stated in tone section and repeated verbatim in Edit tool definition. Triple enforcement with Write tool as well.
evidence: Block A: 'Only use emojis if the user explicitly requests it' / Block B: 'Only use emojis if the user explicitly requests it. Avoid adding emojis to files unless asked.'

description: No-emoji rule from tone section duplicated in Write tool definition.
evidence: Block A: 'Only use emojis if the user explicitly requests it' / Block B: 'Only use emojis if the user explicitly requests it. Avoid writing emojis to files unless asked.'

description: General parallel calls policy says to maximize parallel tool calls. The commit workflow specifically prescribes which calls go in parallel (step 1: git status + diff + log) and which are sequential (step 3: stage, commit, then verify). Both use escalating language ('Maximize' vs step-by-step numbering) without declaring which takes precedence when they apply to the same operation.
evidence: Block A: 'Maximize use of parallel tool calls where possible' / Block B: 'Run git status + git diff + git log in parallel... Add relevant untracked files, create commit, then run git status after'
